comment._content:
As a college student in the 1950's, I worked for a publisher.  The company had a daily newspaper, and printed all kinds of material for businesses.  The shop included several printing presses and six Linotype machine.  My wife of 55 years was a linotype operator when we met.  I did routine maintenence on the Linotypes, served as a substitute proof reader, wrote news, and did just about anything else that was needed. I was the "fill in" guy.

Linotypes always facinated me.  They were very complex machines, but easy to operate.  They had a charactistic sound, with lots of clicking and clattering.  I sometimes found that I was proofing galleys, setting corrections on the Linotype, and inserting the new slugs into the galley.  I worked in the shop, the casting room, the press room and the editorial office, always as the fill in.  

At times, I covered the "police beat" which included the firehouse, courthouse, police department, and city hall.  

Sometimes I wonder if I learned as much at the college as I did at the print shop. Between the two, I think I got a good education.

comment._content:
I, too, remember Linotype machines from my early days as a reporter on local newspapers in the 1960s. As Howard says, the clatter they made was memorable - as was the smell of printers ink, which I loved. The industry was heavily unionised in those days, of course - I don't think they would have stood for the cramped workplace conditions recorded in this evocative image!

Interesting that the man in the foreground (and, no doubt, the others) is wearing a waistcoat and tie. I suppose that kind of attire was de rigueur in those days.
